Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2011 02:18PM SATEX12 wrote: Scuttlers, Thanks a bunch for responding so quickly. This is all such helpful information. My Onc has mentioned to me a few times that she has assisted others with this and how some of those folks have lasted much longer than the "less than one year" stipulation. She told me recently about one young woman that was still going strong 6 years affer cashing her policy! She said that there is a bit of a loophole for patients with cancer because we could, by traditional standards, be given less than a year to live, then a new treatment becomes available that improves our condition or a treatment that was not working previously begins to do so. This is important because even if one survives after collecting on the accelerated benefits, it is not repayable to the insurance company ( nor is it taxable!). I wonder now if my Onc was trying to let me know that she has assisted others in case I need that same assistance...I will mention it to her on my next visit. I have also read up on the topic and found that many insurance companies will pay out the accelerated benefits if someone is deemed "terminally ill" but with a survivability prognosis of greater than one year. I think they have quite a bit of latitude when it comes to this type of situation because it is a very sensitive issue and the last thing they would want is negative publicity by denying someone their benefits under these circumstances. Again, thanks so much for sharing the info. I have learned from it and I know others will as well. I believe my policy has at least a 25% accelerated payout, but the policy face value is for a significant amount so that 25% would be a good size sum of money and would be of great value to my family should my condition deteriorate.
